metadata.name: Wilderness Emergency Procedures Reference
metadata.disclaimer: This information is general wilderness emergency guidance and is not a substitute for professional training or real-time medical or rescue advice. Conditions vary widely; use judgment, prioritize safety, and seek professional help as soon as it becomes available. If you can contact emergency services, do so.

entries.title: STOP: Stop, Think, Observe, Plan
entries.summary: A quick framework to prevent panic-driven mistakes and stabilize the situation.
steps: Stop moving. Sit down if safe. Take 10 slow breaths to reduce panic and improve judgment.
Check immediate dangers: falling rocks, exposure, fire, unstable ice, flash flood zones, hostile wildlife, unsafe terrain.
Assess injuries: you and companions. Control bleeding, stabilize major injuries, prevent shock.
Observe: time of day, weather trend, temperature, wind, daylight remaining, water sources, terrain features, landmarks.
Plan: choose the safest near-term objective (warmth, shelter, water, signaling, staying put).
Assign tasks if in a group: shelter, water collection, signaling setup, fire prep, morale checks.
Re-check frequently: conditions change; update plan every 30–60 minutes or when something changes.
do_not: Do not rush downhill or 'just keep walking' without a plan; this often worsens outcomes.
Do not split up unless there is a compelling reason (e.g., one person must get help and route is certain).
watch_for: Early hypothermia or heat illness reducing decision-making.
Escalating weather (wind shift, darkening clouds, thunder).
notes: In many wilderness incidents, stopping early prevents compounding errors.
A clear plan beats a fast plan.

entries.title: Lost-Person Rule: When to Stay Put vs Move
entries.summary: A decision checklist for whether to remain in place or move deliberately when lost.
steps: Default to staying put if: you are uncertain of your location, visibility is poor, night is approaching, weather is worsening, or you have any injury.
Stay put if you can make yourself findable: visible signals, audible signals, and a safe shelter location.

Consider moving only if ALL apply: you are confident of direction to a known safe point, terrain is safe, you have daylight/time margin, and moving improves rescue odds (e.g., reaching an obvious landmark visible to rescuers).
If you decide to move: do it slowly, mark your path, avoid cliffs/steep drainages, and stop well before darkness.
If a group is involved: keep everyone together unless there is a clearly defined and safe reason to separate (rare).
do_not: Do not wander in circles; it burns energy and reduces rescue probability.
Do not attempt risky shortcuts (steep slopes, unknown river crossings).
watch_for: Sunset and temperature drop timing.
Dehydration or fatigue driving bad choices.
notes: Searchers typically start from the last known point. Staying put preserves that advantage.
If you move, leave obvious indicators of your direction of travel.

entries.title: Backtrack Protocol: Return to Known Point
entries.summary: A cautious method to regain a known trail or landmark without worsening your situation.
steps: Stop and confirm: are you sure you left a known point recently (last 15–60 minutes) and conditions haven’t changed?
If yes and daylight is adequate: turn around and retrace your steps slowly, scanning for your own footprints, broken vegetation, or distinctive markers.
Use deliberate markers as you move: stacked stones, broken twigs, small fabric ties, or distinctive arrangements—visible but minimal impact.
If you fail to regain the known point within a short, pre-set time (e.g., 15–30 minutes), stop and reassess. Consider staying put.
If you regain the trail: stop, hydrate, re-orient, and choose the simplest, safest route to the next known location.
do_not: Do not backtrack into hazardous terrain to 'save time.'
Do not keep increasing your search radius without a time limit.
watch_for: Rapidly fading light or worsening weather.
Terrain traps (cliffs, canyons, thick brush) that make reversing difficult.
notes: Set a strict time limit before you start moving. Stopping early is often the best move.

entries.title: Signaling Principles: Make Yourself Findable
entries.summary: A simple framework for maximizing the chance of detection by aircraft, ground teams, and passersby.
steps: Prioritize high contrast: bright colors against dark ground, dark against snow, reflective against low light.
Use motion: waving, flagging, or moving a reflective surface catches attention better than static objects.
Use patterns recognized as distress: three of anything (3 whistles, 3 fires, 3 flashes) repeated.
Choose a signaling site with visibility: ridgelines, clearings, lakeshores, open slopes (but avoid exposure hazards).
Maintain signals: keep them ready for sudden aircraft/people (mirror accessible, whistle on person).
do_not: Do not rely on one method. Use multiple redundant signals.
Do not put yourself at risk (lightning ridges, unstable cliffs) just to signal.
watch_for: Wind direction for smoke signals.
Aircraft approach angle and sun position for mirrors.
notes: Signaling is most effective when you can sustain it over time.

entries.title: Signal Mirror to Aircraft
entries.summary: Use a mirror or reflective surface to flash sunlight toward aircraft or distant searchers.
steps: Use a purpose-built signal mirror if available. If not, improvise with a phone screen, metal, polished container, or reflective wrapper.
Face the aircraft/search area and hold the mirror near your eye so you can aim precisely.
Make a 'sighting' reference: align the mirror so the reflected bright spot (glint) hits the target area. If you have a mirror with a sighting hole, look through it.
Sweep slowly across the aircraft’s path and horizon to create repeated flashes; flashes are easier to notice than a constant glint.
If the aircraft circles: keep flashing in bursts and maintain position in an open area where you are visible.
If no sun: switch to other signals (smoke, ground symbols, whistle).
do_not: Do not stare into the reflection at full intensity for extended periods.
Do not waste time if conditions prevent reflection; switch methods quickly.
watch_for: Sun angle changes; you may need to relocate slightly.
Fatigue—take turns if in a group.
notes: Even small reflective flashes can be seen from many miles in clear conditions.

entries.title: Ground-to-Air Symbols
entries.summary: Create large, high-contrast markers in open terrain to communicate distress and direction of travel.
steps: Select an open, visible area: meadow, gravel bar, shoreline, open slope, ridgeline bench (avoid hazards).
Build large symbols using rocks, logs, branches, or scraped earth. Aim for big, bold lines with strong contrast.
Use 'SOS' if possible. If materials are limited, use a large 'X' to indicate distress and need of assistance.
If you are moving, add an arrow indicating direction of travel and leave a note if you can (time, destination, party size).
Maintain the symbol: keep it clear of drifting snow, blowing debris, or shadowing when possible.
do_not: Do not build small or intricate symbols—bigger and simpler is better.
Do not choose areas prone to sudden flooding (dry streambeds) just for visibility.
watch_for: Rising water levels, tides, or rapidly changing weather.
Vegetation fire risk if you add signal fires nearby.
notes: Size matters. Think in terms of what is visible from far above, not from where you stand.

entries.title: Signal Fire and Smoke
entries.summary: Use fire for visibility at night and smoke for daytime aircraft detection.
steps: Build a safe fire base: clear flammables, use mineral soil or rocks, and pick a location protected from spreading fire.
Prepare fuel BEFORE lighting: dry tinder/kindling plus larger fuel; then gather smoke-making materials separately (green boughs, damp leaves) for daytime.
For daytime smoke: once a stable fire exists, add green or damp vegetation in short bursts to create thick white smoke.
For night signaling: maintain a bright flame and consider arranging multiple fires (e.g., three fires in a triangle or line) if resources allow and it is safe.
Keep an extinguisher plan: water, dirt, or sand ready. Never leave signal fires unattended.
If aircraft is spotted: add smoke immediately to increase contrast and draw attention.
do_not: Do not start a fire in extreme wind, drought, or near heavy fuels where it could spread uncontrollably.
Do not build fires under low branches or in peat/duff that can smolder underground.
watch_for: Shifting wind direction and ember carry.
Dehydration and fatigue while tending fire.
notes: If fire risk is high, prioritize other signals (mirror, whistle, bright panels).

entries.title: Audible Signaling
entries.summary: Use standardized sound patterns to attract rescuers without exhausting yourself.
steps: Use a whistle if available; it carries farther and saves your voice.
Signal in groups of three: 3 sharp blasts, pause, repeat after a longer pause.
Between signal cycles, listen carefully for response; rescuers may answer with their own pattern.
Conserve energy: use periodic signaling rather than constant yelling.
If someone is searching nearby, increase frequency and add visual motion (waving bright cloth).
do_not: Do not scream continuously; you can lose your voice quickly and become dehydrated.
Do not ignore a reply—stop and listen to triangulate direction.
watch_for: Echoes in canyons that make direction confusing.
Wind direction affecting sound travel.
notes: A whistle on your person (not in your pack) is a high-value item.

entries.title: If You Can Contact Help: What to Say
entries.summary: A checklist for communicating critical details fast when you have brief signal or radio contact.
steps: State the emergency clearly: injury/illness/exposure/lost/vehicle issue.
Give location: GPS coordinates if possible, plus descriptive landmarks (trail name, nearest junction, elevation, mile marker).
Give party info: number of people, ages, condition of each, supplies available, shelter status.
Describe hazards: weather, terrain, water crossings, wildlife risk, avalanche/flash flood concerns.
Give plan: whether you are staying put or moving, and your intended route/destination if moving.
Conserve battery: switch to airplane mode when not actively communicating; keep phone warm in cold.
do_not: Do not exaggerate or guess location if you are unsure; say what you know and what you don’t.
Do not drain battery attempting constant calls; schedule check-ins if possible.
watch_for: Battery failure in cold temperatures.
Poor reception causing dropped calls—prioritize location first.
notes: If you have a texting option, texts may go through when voice won’t.

entries.title: SAR Reality
entries.summary: Behaviors that make you easier to find and safer while SAR operations occur.
steps: Assume SAR starts from your last known point and expands outward based on terrain and probability.
Increase detectability: bright items visible from above, reflective flashes, audible signaling cycles.
Choose a safe, visible shelter location near open terrain if possible.
Make your camp obvious: laid-out gear, contrasting tarp, large ground markings.
If you must move, leave clear information: direction of travel, date/time, party size, condition, and intended destination.
If you hear aircraft or searchers: go to your prepared signal point and signal immediately.
Stay calm and conserve energy—survival and signaling outrank constant movement.
do_not: Do not hide under dense canopy if avoidable; it blocks visibility and sound.
Do not chase aircraft; stay in your visible area and keep signaling.
watch_for: Nighttime temperature drops and wet clothing—hypothermia risk rises during passive waiting.
Overexertion when trying to 'help SAR' by moving too much.
notes: Your job is to be safe, stay alive, and be detectable.

entries.title: Helicopter Approach Safety
entries.summary: Reduce risk to yourself and rescuers during rotor wash and landing operations.
steps: Secure loose items: hats, tarps, lightweight gear can become dangerous projectiles.
Stay low and stable; protect your eyes from dust/debris.
Approach only if clearly signaled by crew. If instructed to approach, approach from the front or as directed; never from the rear.
Keep hands visible and avoid sudden movements; follow instructions exactly.
Keep others (especially children/pets) close and controlled.
do_not: Do not approach without being waved in by the crew.
Do not run toward the aircraft; rotor wash can knock you down and debris can blind you.
watch_for: Flying debris and unstable footing.
Hearing protection needs; communicate with gestures if necessary.
notes: Rotor blades can be hard to see; respect distance and instructions.

entries.title: Evacuation Go/No-Go Assessment
entries.summary: A structured way to decide whether to self-evacuate or shelter and signal.
steps: Assess medical status: can you walk safely? Is there bleeding, head injury signs, severe pain, or altered mental status?
Assess environment: weather trend, temperature, precipitation, wind, lightning, avalanche/flash flood risk.
Assess time: daylight remaining, distance to known help, terrain difficulty.
Assess resources: water, insulation, fire capability, navigation tools, calories, footwear condition.
Choose the lower-risk option: staying put and signaling is often safer than moving injured or late in the day.
If you evacuate: pick the simplest route (known trail/road), move slowly, and stop well before exhaustion.
If you stay: improve shelter, conserve heat, set up signals, and maintain a routine.
do_not: Do not force a walk-out with a suspected serious injury or severe hypothermia/heat illness.
Do not attempt technical terrain when you are impaired or fatigued.
watch_for: Rapid weather shifts that can trap you mid-route.
Injury worsening under load.
notes: The safest choice is the one that prevents you from becoming harder to rescue.

entries.title: Evacuating an Injured Person
entries.summary: Options for moving an injured person when staying put is more dangerous than moving.
steps: Decide if moving is truly necessary: exposure hazards (incoming storm, rising water, rockfall) may force relocation.
Prefer assisted walking if possible: use a stick as a cane, or two-person support (human crutch).
If non-weight-bearing: consider a drag method on durable material (tarp, jacket, poncho, sleeping pad) over smooth terrain.
If you have multiple helpers and materials: create a litter with two poles and a jacket/tarp woven between them, or a rigid pad strapped to poles.
Secure the patient: prevent rolling, pad pressure points, keep them warm and protected from wind.
Move slowly and communicate; stop often to re-check circulation, pain, and condition.
Mark your route and keep signaling ability active if SAR may be nearby.
do_not: Do not attempt long carries over rough terrain; it exhausts rescuers and increases risk of falls.
Do not worsen spinal injury risk with rough handling if spinal injury is suspected.
watch_for: Shock, hypothermia, pain escalation, and loss of consciousness.
Rescuer fatigue leading to accidents.
notes: If evacuation is required, shorter moves to safer shelter can be more realistic than reaching 'help' in one push.

entries.title: Survive-the-Night Priorities (Shelter First)
entries.summary: A practical checklist to reduce exposure risk when rescue may take time.
steps: Get out of wind and wet conditions: windbreak, tarp, natural barrier, or improvised lean-to.
Insulate from the ground: pile dry vegetation, use a pad, pack, rope coils, or spare clothing under your torso.
Stay dry: change into dry layers if available; wring wet items and keep them near body heat only if safe.
Create a heat strategy: fire if safe, or huddle, or heat-retaining shelter design.
Hydrate and eat if possible: dehydration and low calories accelerate cold injury.
Set signals before sleeping: visible marker, reflective item ready, whistle on person.
Establish a routine: check companions, maintain fire safely if used, and keep morale steady.
do_not: Do not sleep directly on cold ground without insulation if you can avoid it.
Do not shelter in dry creek beds or areas with flash flood potential.
watch_for: Shivering that becomes uncontrolled, confusion, or clumsiness (hypothermia).
Wetness creeping into insulation layers.
notes: Warmth is often the limiting factor in wilderness emergencies.

entries.title: Movement Rules If You Must Travel While Lost
entries.summary: Guidance to reduce risk while moving in uncertain terrain.
steps: Move only with a clear plan: destination, route, and turnaround time.
Avoid terrain traps: cliff bands, steep gullies, thick brush, river canyons with no exits.
Follow handrails when appropriate: ridgelines (if safe), streams (with caution), trails, roads, power lines.
Leave markers: clear directional indicators and notes with time/date if possible.
Stop early for shelter: do not push into darkness or exhaustion.
Maintain detectability: keep bright items visible; signal from open areas periodically.
Check navigation frequently: do not walk long distances without confirming direction.
do_not: Do not descend blindly into drainages; it can commit you to hazardous terrain.
Do not cross fast-moving water if avoidable.
watch_for: Foot hot spots and blisters—treat early to preserve mobility.
Overheating or dehydration during exertion.
notes: A safe, slower route is better than a fast risky one.

entries.title: Emergency Water
entries.summary: How to prioritize hydration and reduce dehydration risk while waiting or traveling.
steps: Ration effort, not water: drink when you have water; dehydration impairs judgment and thermoregulation.
Reduce loss: stay in shade when hot, reduce sweating by slowing pace, and add wind protection when cold.
Seek reliable sources: flowing streams, springs, seeps; collect rainwater when possible.
If you have treatment: filter/boil/chemical treat per your available method.
If no treatment: assess risk and decide based on survival need; avoid stagnant, algae-heavy, or animal-contaminated water if possible.
Carry water securely and prevent freezing in cold by keeping it near your body or insulated.
do_not: Do not drink seawater or urine; these worsen dehydration.
Do not exert heavily at the hottest part of the day if low on water.
watch_for: Dark urine, dizziness, headache, confusion.
Cramping or heat illness signs.
notes: Hydration helps prevent both heat and cold injury.

entries.title: Fire Use in Emergencies
entries.summary: Use fire for warmth and signaling when it can be done safely.
steps: Confirm fire is safe and permitted: wind, dryness, local restrictions, and fuel type matter.
Build in a safe location: clear a wide area, use mineral soil/rock base, avoid roots/duff.
Gather enough fuel first to maintain warmth through critical hours (especially after sunset).
Use reflectors: rock wall, log reflector, or space blanket behind you to bounce heat.
Keep fire modest: a small controlled fire often provides enough heat and is easier to manage.
Extinguish fully before leaving or sleeping if you cannot maintain safe control.
do_not: Do not build fire in high wind or severe drought conditions where it could escape.
Do not use flammable fuels near shelter materials.
watch_for: Embers drifting, ground smoldering, sudden wind gusts.
Smoke inhalation in enclosed shelters.
notes: Warmth can be achieved without fire using insulation and wind protection; fire is optional if unsafe.

entries.title: Wildlife and Environmental Hazards
entries.summary: General guidance to reduce risk from common hazards while lost or awaiting rescue.
steps: Keep food and scented items secured and away from sleeping area if possible.
Avoid moving at dawn/dusk in dense brush when visibility is low, especially if stressed and tired.
Lightning: get off exposed ridges/summits; avoid isolated tall trees; adopt a low, insulated position if caught in the open.
Flash floods: stay out of dry washes and narrow canyons when storms are possible upstream.
Snakes: watch hand/foot placement; do not reach into crevices; use a stick to probe.
If you encounter aggressive wildlife: back away slowly, make yourself look larger, and do not run.
do_not: Do not store food in your shelter or clothing pockets while sleeping if you can avoid it.
Do not cross swollen rivers if another option exists.
watch_for: Thunder in the distance (lightning risk can extend far from storm).
Water level rising quickly or debris flow sounds.
notes: In emergencies, avoid adding a second emergency (injury) to the first.

entries.title: Improvised Signal Panels and Flags
entries.summary: Build highly visible signals using what you have and what you can gather.
steps: Use the brightest available material: rain jacket, sleeping pad, tarp, bandana, emergency blanket, shirt.
Create contrast: lay bright item on dark ground; on snow, use dark logs/rocks or dirt to outline.
Add motion: tie cloth to a pole/branch and wave, or rig it to flutter in wind.
If no bright gear: scrape ground to create light/dark contrast, arrange stones/logs in bold shapes.
Place signals in the most visible safe location, then keep a path back to shelter.
do_not: Do not sacrifice critical insulation layers if doing so risks hypothermia.
Do not place signals in hazardous exposure zones (lightning ridges, unstable slopes).
watch_for: Wind tearing fabric or blowing panels away—anchor securely.
Snowfall covering ground symbols—refresh as needed.
notes: A visible panel plus a whistle plus a mirror is a strong combination.
